The development of the [[elevator]] was also essential to the emergence of the early skyscrapers, as office buildings taller than around six stories would have been impractical without them.<ref name=LandauConditP35>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|p=35}}; {{harvnb|Abramson|2001|p=84}}</ref> Powered elevators were first installed in England during the 1830s and spread to U.S. factories and hotels by the 1840s.<ref name=LandauConditP35/> Elevators using hoist ropes, however, could only function effectively in low-rise buildings, and this limitation encouraged the introduction of the hydraulic elevator in 1870, even though early models contained dangerous design flaws.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|p=36}}</ref> By 1876 these problems had been resolved, providing a solution for servicing the early skyscrapers.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=36–37}}; {{harvnb|Ford|2005|p=21}}</ref>
New environmental technologies in heating, lighting, [[Ventilation (architecture)|ventilation]] and sanitation were also critical to creating taller buildings that were attractive to work in. [[Central heating]] could not be easily extended to serve larger buildings;<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=30–31}}</ref> in the 1850s, a system using low-pressure steam and steam-operated fans became adopted in the construction of the later skyscrapers.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|p=30}}</ref> Many U.S. buildings were [[gas light|lit by gas]], but this carried safety risks and was difficult to install in taller buildings.<ref name=LandauConditP38>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|p=38}}</ref> As an alternative, [[electric light]]s were installed from 1878 onwards, powered by basement generators.<ref name=LandauConditP38/> Ventilation was also a challenge, as smoke drifting into offices from the streets and the fumes from the gas lighting made [[Indoor air quality|air quality]] a major health issue.<ref name=LandauConditP32>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|p=32}}</ref> A steam-driven, forced-draft ventilation system was invented in 1860 and became widely used in taller buildings by the 1870s, overcoming much of the problem.<ref name=LandauConditP32/> Improvements in iron piping permitted running hot and cold water and sanitation facilities to be installed throughout taller buildings for the first time.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=33–34}}</ref>
==Emergence of the skyscraper: 1880–99==
===The first skyscraper=== [[File:Home Insurance Building.JPG|thumb|Chicago's [[Home Insurance Building]] in 1884, often considered the world's first skyscraper]] There is academic disagreement over which building should be considered the first skyscraper.<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|p=5}}; {{harvnb|Condit|1968|p=114}}</ref> The term was first used in the 1780s to describe a particularly tall horse, before later being applied to the [[Sail-plan|sail at the top of a ship's mast]], tall hats and bonnets, tall men, and a ball that was hit high into the air.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|p=ix}}</ref> In the 1880s it began to be applied to buildings, first in 1883 to describe large public monuments and then in 1889 as a label for tall office blocks, coming into widespread use over the next decade.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=ix–x}}; {{harvnb|Condit|1968|p=115}}</ref> Identifying the first "true skyscraper" is not straightforward, and various candidates exist depending on the criteria applied.<ref>{{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|p=23}}</ref> George Post's New York [[Equitable Life Building (New York City)|Equitable Life Building]] of 1870, for example, was the first tall office building to use the elevator, while his [[2 Broadway|Produce Exchange]] building of 1884 made substantial structural advances in metal frame design.<ref>{{harvnb|Condit|1968|pp=116–117}}; {{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|p=23}}</ref> The [[Home Insurance Building]] in Chicago, opened in 1885, is, however, most often labelled the first skyscraper because of its innovative use of structural steel in a metal frame design.<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|p=5}}; {{harvnb|Condit|1968|p=115}}; {{harvnb|Ford|2005|p=22}}</ref>
The Home Insurance Building was a {{convert|138|ft|adj=on}} tall, 10-story skyscraper designed by [[William Le Baron Jenney]], who had been trained as an engineer in France and was a leading architect in Chicago.<ref>{{harvnb|Condit|1968|pp=123–124}}; {{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|p=22}}</ref>{{refn|Sources during the period covered by this article often vary in their calculation of how many stories an early skyscraper had, depending on how they were counted and what material the writer drew on.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=xiv–xv}}</ref>|group=nb}} Jenney's design was unusual in that it incorporated [[structural steel]] into the building's internal metal frame alongside the traditional wrought iron. This frame took the weight of the floors of the building and helped to support the weight of the external walls as well, proving an important step towards creating the genuine non-structural [[curtain wall (architecture)|curtain walls]] that became a feature of later skyscrapers.<ref>{{harvnb|Condit|1968|pp=124–125}}</ref> The design was not perfect – some of the weight was still carried by masonry walls, and the metal frame was bolted, rather than [[rivet]]ed, together – but it was clearly a significant advance in tall building construction.<ref name="Condit 1968 125"/>
The approach quickly caught on in Chicago. In 1889 the [[Tacoma Building (Chicago)|Tacoma Building]] replaced the bolted metal design with a stronger riveted approach, and Chicago's Chamber of Commerce Building introduced interior light courts to the structural design of skyscrapers.<ref name=ConditP126>{{harvnb|Condit|1968|p=126}}</ref> The 1890 [[Rand McNally Building]] became the first entirely self-supporting, steel-framed skyscraper.<ref name=ConditP126/> Some buildings, such as [[Rookery Building|The Rookery]] and the [[Monadnock Building]], combined elements of both the newer and older styles, but generally Chicago rapidly adopted steel structures as a flexible and effective way to produce a range of tall buildings.<ref>{{harvnb|Condit|1968|p=127}}</ref> [[Structural engineer]]s specializing in the steel frame design began to establish practices in Chicago.<ref>{{harvnb|Fenske|2005|p=20}}</ref>
[[File:Newspaper Row, 1906.JPG|thumb|250px|left|[[Park Row (Manhattan)|Park Row]] in New York had several early skyscrapers built for newspaper companies clustered around the [[New York City Hall|City Hall]]]]
There was a boom in skyscraper construction in Chicago from 1888 onwards.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=5}}</ref> By 1893, Chicago had built 12 skyscrapers between 16 and 20 stories tall, tightly clustered in the center of the financial district.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=50}}; {{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|p=112}}</ref> Chicago's skyscrapers, however, were constrained by the contemporary limits of steel-frame design and the muddy sub-soil in the city, which together limited most of their skyscrapers to around 16 or 17 stories.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=52}}</ref> Chicago's skyscrapers rapidly became tourist destinations for the views of the wider city they provided from their upper floors and as attractive sites in their own right.<ref>{{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|pp=114–115}}</ref> Tourists were advised to hire cabs for street tours of the skyscrapers – by lying back in the cab, they would be able to safely take in the tops of the tall buildings.<ref name="Bluestone 1991 145">{{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|p=145}}</ref>
The [[Masonic Temple (Chicago)|Masonic Temple]] was the most prominent of these skyscrapers. Built by the [[Freemasonry|Freemasons]] of Chicago in 1892, at a time when the Masons was a fast-growing social community, the lavish {{convert|302|ft|adj=on}} tall skyscraper had 19 stories, the bottom ten holding shops and the higher levels containing the Masons' private suites and meeting halls, some able to hold up to 1,300 people.<ref>{{harvnb|Wolner|2005|p=101}}</ref> At the top was a roof garden and observation gallery.<ref>{{harvnb|Wolner|2005|pp=108, 113}}</ref> The Freemasons were competing with their local rivals the [[Independent Order of Odd Fellows|Odd Fellows]], who intended to build a much higher skyscraper, {{convert|556|ft}} tall, that they announced would be the tallest building in the world.<ref>{{harvnb|Wolner|2005|pp=103–104, 106}}</ref> Newspapers picked up the story, circulating facts about the size of the Temple and making comparison to historical buildings such as the [[United States Capitol|Capitol]] or the [[Statue of Liberty]].<ref>{{harvnb|Wolner|2005|pp=108, 110}}</ref> The Odd Fellows project failed, but the Masonic Temple capitalized on the publicity, being declared the "tallest commercial building in the world".<ref>{{harvnb|Wolner|2005|p=114}}</ref>{{refn|Despite the positive publicity at the time, the stores in the Masonic Temple had mostly failed by 1897.<ref>{{harvnb|Wolner|2005|p=112}}</ref>|group=nb}}
In comparison, New York trailed behind Chicago, having only four buildings over 16 stories tall by 1893.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=50}}</ref> Part of the delay was caused by the slowness of the city authorities to authorize metal-frame construction techniques; it was not until 1889 that they relented and allowed [[Bradford Gilbert]] to construct the [[Tower Building (New York City)|Tower Building]], an 11-story iron-framed skyscraper.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=9}}; {{harvnb|Condit|1968|p=118}}</ref> This encouraged the building of more skyscrapers in New York, although the city remained cautious about the technology for some years.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=9}}; {{harvnb|Condit|1968|p=119}}</ref> Finally, in 1895 a breakthrough was made with the construction of the [[American Surety Building]], a twenty-story, {{convert|303|ft|adj=on}} high-steel development that broke Chicago's height record.<ref name=ConditP119>{{harvnb|Condit|1968|p=119}}</ref> From then on, New York thoroughly embraced skeleton frame construction.<ref name=ConditP119/> In particular, New York newspaper companies adopted the skyscraper, building several along [[Park Row (Manhattan)|Park Row]], sometimes termed "Newspaper Row", in the 1880s and 1890s.<ref>{{harvnb|Gray|2005|pp=95–96}}</ref> A few early skyscrapers were also constructed in Baltimore, Boston, Pittsburgh, St. Louis, Rochester, and Buffalo, such as the [[Wainwright Building]], [[Wilder Building]], and [[Prudential (Guaranty) Building|Guaranty Building]].<ref>{{harvnb|Ford|2005|p=25}}; {{harvnb|Revell|2005|p=43}}; refs for buildings needed.</ref> Early examples on the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]] include the [[Old Chronicle Building]] and the [[Call Building]] in [[San Francisco]],<ref>{{harvnb|Tobriner|2006|pp=86–90}}</ref> as well as the [[Luzon Building]] in [[Tacoma, Washington]].<ref>{{harvnb|Gallacci|Karabaich|2009|p=42}}</ref>
===Architectural challenges=== {{main|Chicago school (architecture)|l1=Chicago School of Architecture|Architecture of New York City}} [[File:Chicago Masonic Temple Building.jpg|thumb|Chicago's [[Masonic Temple (Chicago)|Masonic Temple Building]] depicted in 1909, showing the tripartite division of the building's exterior and the typical Chicago window bays]] The architects of early skyscrapers faced a number of challenges. The most fashionable architectural style in the late 19th century was the French [[Beaux-Arts architecture|Beaux-Arts]] movement, sometimes termed the Italian Renaissance style, which applied [[Classical architecture|Classical]] aesthetic principles to modern buildings.<ref name=LandauConditP185>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|p=185}}</ref> American architects trained in the Beaux-Arts style at the Parisian [[Académie des Beaux-Arts]] began to return home in the 1880s, bringing these ideals and standards with them. Applying contemporary Beaux-Arts standards to early skyscrapers, however, was not straightforward. The buildings that the Beaux-Arts movement influenced were typically much shorter and broader than any skyscraper, and it was difficult to accurately reproduce the style in a tall, narrow building.<ref name=LandauConditP185/>
Skyscrapers were also primarily commercial buildings, and economics as well as aesthetics had to play an important part in their design.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=14–15}}</ref> The architectural writer Barr Ferree noted in 1893 that "current American architecture is not a matter of art, but of business. A building must pay, or there will be no investor ready with the money to meet its cost. This is at once the curse and the glory of American architecture."<ref>{{harvnb|Ferree|1893|p=231}} cited {{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=15}}</ref> George Hill echoed the theme, condemning unnecessary features on the basis that "every cubic foot that is used for purely ornamental purposes beyond that needed to express its use and to make it harmonize with others of its class, is a waste".<ref>{{harvnb|Hill|1904|p=313}} cited {{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=15}}</ref>
By the 1890s, Chicago architects were producing a solution to this problem, creating a new architectural style, often termed the "Chicago school of architecture".<ref name="Willis 1995 11">{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=11}}</ref>{{refn|Although often being referred to as the "Chicago school of architecture" it is unclear if there was an organised body of architectural thought in Chicago during the period and the views of individual architects varied on many issues.<ref>{{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|pp=105–106}}; {{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=11}}; {{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|p=21}}</ref>|group=nb}} The school included architects such as [[Louis Sullivan]], William Le Baron Jenney and [[John Wellborn Root|John Root]], whose designs combined architectural aesthetic theory with practical commercial sense. They favoured placing rich, ornate designs on the outside of skyscrapers at the ground level and simpler, plainer ornamentation on the upper levels, with strong vertical lines.<ref>{{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|pp=143–144}}; {{harvnb|Bragdon|2003|p=158}}</ref> The roofs of their skyscrapers typically formed a comprehensible outline and structure when seen at a distance as part of the city skyline. The intent was to draw the observer's eye upwards, celebrating what Sullivan termed the "lofty" nature of the skyscraper, but not wasting resources on intricate detailing unlikely to appeal to a busy businessman.<ref>{{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|pp=143–144}}; {{harvnb|Bragdon|2003|p=158}}; Root, p.71, cited {{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|p=115}}</ref> At the same time, the more lavish ground floor designs would make the building stand out to passers-by and pull in the necessary business for a successful commercial building.<ref>{{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|pp=144–145}}</ref>
[[File:New York Times Building 41 Park Row from north.jpg|thumb|left|The [[New York Times Building (41 Park Row)|New York Times Building]] in 2012, showing the multitude of different styles on a single façade typical of the city's early skyscrapers]] This community also saw close collaboration between architects, specialist structural engineers, and building contractors emerge on the new skyscraper projects.<ref name="Fenske 2005 21">{{harvnb|Fenske|2005|p=21}}</ref> Historically the industry had been dominated by individuals and small firms who combined the roles of architect and engineer, but this broke down in Chicago during the period, being replaced by a partnership between specialist architects who focused on the appearance of the skyscraper, and specialist engineers who focused on the structures that enabled it to be built.<ref>{{harvnb|Fenske|2005|pp=26–27}}</ref> Chicago architectural firms grew to be large, hierarchical and with numerous specialist staff; the [[D. H. Burnham & Company]], for example, felt like a small factory to visitors, and ultimately expanded to employ 180 staff.<ref>{{harvnb|Fenske|2005|p=24}}</ref>
The resulting [[Chicago school (architecture)|Chicago school]] produced large, solid-looking skyscrapers, built with a common appearance and to a common height.<ref name="Willis 1995 11"/> The result was usually a box-like ''palazzo'', illuminated with a large light court, ideally, if space allowed, in the center.<ref name="Willis 1995 23">{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=23}}</ref> The outside of the building was commonly divided into three parts: a base, middle section and the roof line. This tripartite design was intended both to emulate classical columns, and reflect the functions of the different parts of the skyscraper.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=185–186}}</ref> The central court could form a simple courtyard, but many companies preferred to roof over the courtyard with glass to produce an [[Atrium (architecture)|atrium]] for shops and restaurants.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=57}}</ref> Rents for these shops were up to five or six times that for office space, and made an important difference to the income from a property.<ref name="Willis 1995 58">{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=58}}</ref> Chicago skyscraper windows were also a feature of the style; these were large, fixed windows flanked by smaller [[sash window]]s on either side, which provided access to sunlight and adequate ventilation. Sometimes these protruded from the building to form a slight bay.<ref>{{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|p=135}}</ref>
Although the exterior of the Chicago skyscrapers buildings were relatively plain, the entrance ways and lobbies were fitted out in a grand style.<ref>{{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|p=119}}</ref> The [[Unity Building (Chicago)|Unity Building]], for example, was reported as including "Numidian, Alps, Green and Sienna marbles ... an artistic screen of glass and bronze ... a marble balcony" alongside "Corinthian columns with finely carved capitals, gold-leaf and silver chandeliers, and silver-plated latticework" on the elevators.<ref>{{harvnb|Flinn|1893|p=197}} cited {{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|p=119}}; {{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|p=119}}</ref> The aim was to project a sense of prosperity and solid financial credentials, which in turn would attract tenants willing to pay high rents.<ref>{{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|p=123}}</ref> For the tenants, such surroundings were good for their own business credibility and affirmed their own social status as professionals.<ref>{{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|pp=123–138}}</ref>
New York faced similar architectural challenges, but in comparison to Chicago, skyscraper architects worked less closely with engineers and other specialists, and instead held strong backgrounds in the Beaux Arts movement and perceived their role to be primarily artistic rather than a partnership with the mechanical arts.<ref name="Fenske 2005 21"/> Their practices tended to be smaller, resembling ''atelier'' style workshops.<ref>{{harvnb|Fenske|2005|p=25}}</ref> Structural engineers in New York took longer to build up a strong professional role there, a trend reflected in the lower engineering quality of many early skyscrapers in the city.<ref>{{harvnb|Fenske|2005|p=27}}</ref> The New York style emphasized stunning height and a somewhat eclectic use of architectural features from other periods, creating an energetic, flamboyant appearance.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=11–12}}; {{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|p=26}}</ref> Towers were common, making best use of the relatively small plots of land in New York.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=23, 40}}</ref> Some New York skyscrapers emulated the tripartite style of Chicago, but others broke their exterior down into many different layers, each with its own style.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|p=186}}</ref> Proponents argued that this reintroduced a sense of human proportion to these tall buildings; critics felt that the results were confusing and ungainly.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=184–186}}</ref>
===Life in early skyscrapers=== [[File:Plan of Chicago Stock Exchange.png|thumb|250px|Plan of a typical level of the [[Chicago Stock Exchange|Chicago Stock Exchange Building]], 1893; A – court; B – hall; C – toilet; D – barbershop; E – vents; F – [[flue]]; G – office, {{convert|12|ft}} by {{convert|19|ft}}]] Early skyscrapers were mainly made up of small office cubicles, commonly only {{convert|12|ft}} across, which were placed adjacent to one another along long corridors, following a pattern first invented in the [[Oriel Chambers]] building in England in 1864.<ref name=FordP24>{{harvnb|Ford|2005|p=24}}</ref> This allowed the average small company to rent a small amount of space using one or two offices, but held out the option for future expansion by renting additional office cubicles if required at a later date.<ref name=FordP24/> A skyscraper office relied on natural sunlight from the windows but if necessary was dimly lit from electric desk-top lamps.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=24}}</ref> By the standards of the day, these offices were very modern, with radiators, air vents, and the latest fixtures and fittings, and modern communication systems, including telephone and [[pneumatic tube]]s were often installed.<ref name=BluestonePP128>{{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|pp=128, 132}}</ref> As a result, many businesses chose to move out of their older, low-rise offices in Chicago to take up tenancy in the new skyscrapers, which were felt to be more convenient and healthier.<ref name=BluestonePP128/>
The first skyscrapers were mainly occupied by male workers, but this changed during the 1890s, with female employees becoming more common. The percentage of female clerical workers in Chicago, for example, increased from 11 percent in 1880 to 21 percent by 1890, reaching 30 percent by 1900.<ref>{{harvnb|Fine|2005|pp=64–65, 69}}</ref> Various moral concerns were raised about men and women mixing in such offices, which were characterized as being masculine spaces, full of tobacco smoke and profanity and therefore unsuitable for women.<ref>{{harvnb|Fine|2005|pp=68–70}}</ref> The new female workers typically worked as typists or [[stenographer]]s, using the recently invented [[typewriter]], which grew in number in U.S. offices from 146 in 1879 to 65,000 by 1890.<ref>{{harvnb|Fine|2005|p=73}}</ref>
Skyscrapers provided a wide range of in-house services for their tenants, including shops, restaurants, barbers, tobacconists, newsagents, tailors, professional specialists and libraries.<ref name=BluestoneP141>{{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|p=141}}</ref> Skyscrapers also employed a substantial number of service staff to maintain and support them; a building such as the Chicago Board of Trade spent 20 percent of its rental revenue on service staff, employing 41 people, including janitors, elevator operators, engineers, and an electrician.<ref name=BluestoneP141/> With this collection of services and facilities, skyscrapers of the period were often referred to as small cities in their own right.<ref name="Bluestone 1991 145"/>
===Criticism and reform in Chicago===
Opposition to Chicago's skyscrapers began to grow during the late 1880s and early 1890s.<ref name=BluestoneP150>{{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|p=150}}</ref> Even before the development of the skyscraper, some criticized large buildings in Chicago for dominating churches and private houses, and this sentiment strengthened.<ref>{{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|pp=5, 150}}</ref> Critics complained that the concentration of tall buildings in the center of the city was causing huge congestion, and each new skyscraper was also burning additional coal to power its facilities, together consuming a total of over one million tons each year, leaving smoke and stagnant air hanging over Chicago.<ref name=BluestoneP150/> Many were concerned over the risk of a major fire breaking out and spreading, uncontrolled, from building to building.<ref name=BluestoneP150/>
Chicago was not alone in having concerns over the growth of the skyscraper. In Boston, the Fiske and the [[Ames Building]]s were built in the late 1880s, {{convert|183|ft|abbr=on}} and {{convert|190|ft}} tall respectively, but protests by local civic campaigners and the real estate industry resulted in the city passing a law to limit new buildings to a maximum of {{convert|123|ft}}, effectively banning the construction of skyscrapers.<ref name=RevellP43>{{harvnb|Revell|2005|p=43}}</ref> The cities of Philadelphia, Los Angeles and Washington D.C. similarly introduced [[height restriction laws]] to limit skyscraper construction.<ref>{{harvnb|Ford|2005|p=31}}</ref>
The decisive factor in favor of change in Chicago, however, was the economic slowdown in the early 1890s, which gave way to the financial [[panic of 1893]].<ref name=BluestonsP150WillisP9>{{harvnb|Bluestone|1991|p=150}}; {{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=9}}</ref> The recession, combined with the frantic building of the previous few years, meant that Chicago suddenly had a significant surplus of office space, threatening occupancy levels and rents.<ref name=BluestonsP150WillisP9/> Regulation was introduced by the city council to control the problem in 1892, with support from the real estate industry who hoped to slow the construction of additional office space and shore up their diminishing profit margins.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=9}}</ref> The height of new buildings was limited to {{convert|150|ft}}, with lower height levels on narrower streets, effectively curtailing the construction of any taller skyscrapers.<ref name=BluestonsP150WillisP9/>
==The "First Great Age": 1900–19== [[File:The Skyscrapers of New York (1906).webm|thumb|''The Skyscrapers of New York'', a 1906 film.]] ===Pre-war boom===
The early years of the 20th century saw a range of technically sophisticated, architecturally confident skyscrapers built in New York; academics Sarah Landau and Carl Condit term this "the first great age" of skyscraper building.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=298, 395}}</ref> Some were relatively conservative buildings in a classical style, such as the Mutual Life, [[Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company|Atlantic Mutual]], and [[Broad Exchange Building]]s, all designed by [[Clinton and Russell]].<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=288–399}}</ref> Others broke new ground, including the [[Flatiron Building]] which opened in 1903 near Madison Square.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|p=301}}</ref> The Chicago firm of Daniel Hudsdon Burnham designed the {{convert|307|ft}} high, 21 story structure; the unusually shaped, narrow building needed particularly strong wind bracing, while the facade was richly textured and incorporated stylistic features more common in Chicago.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=302–304}}</ref> A critical and popular success, the Flatiron was likened to the [[Parthenon]] of Ancient Greece and became a New York icon.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=302–304}}; {{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|p=38}}</ref>
The construction of the [[Singer Tower]] was announced by the company in 1906, who intended to produce the tallest skyscraper in the world.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=354–355}}</ref> The company already had several low-rise buildings in New York that the tower would be incorporated into and planned to rent out the bottom half of the tower to tenants to subsidize their use of the upper half.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|p=355}}</ref> The skyscraper was designed by [[Ernest Flagg]], a Beaux-Arts advocate and noted critic of existing skyscrapers, who justified taking on the project as a way of generating support for skyscraper reform.<ref name="Fenske 2005 22">{{harvnb|Fenske|2005|p=22}}</ref> The design was technically challenging: the tall, narrow tower needed special wind bracing, and the deep bedrock on the site required particularly deep foundations.<ref name="Landau 1996 357">{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|p=357}}</ref> The tower was faced in dark brick and followed the Beaux-Arts style used by the rest of the complex, with a galleried lobby fitted out in Italian marble.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=359–361}}</ref> When it opened in 1908, it had 47 stories and was {{convert|612|ft}} tall; visitors paid $0.50 ($12 in 2010 terms) each to use the observation area at the top of the building.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|p=354}}</ref>
[[File:Woolworth Building and City Hall Park, New York City 1910s retouched.png|thumb|300px|left|Color postcard of "The [[Woolworth Building]] and [[New York City Hall|City Hall Park]], New York City" around 1913, when it was the world's-tallest building]]
The [[Metropolitan Life Insurance Company Tower]] was opened in 1909, the culmination of a long building project by [[Napoleon LeBrun|N. LeBrun and Sons]] to hold Metropolitan Life's growing headquarters staff, 2,800 strong by 1909.<ref>{{harvnb|Moudry|2005b|pp=120–125}}; {{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|p=361}}</ref> At {{convert|700|ft}} high and with 50 stories, it became the world's new tallest building.<ref>{{harvnb|Moudry|2005b|pp=123–125}}</ref> Metropolitan Life intended the skyscraper to promote the company's image, and the building was surrounded by publicity.<ref>{{harvnb|Moudry|2005b|pp=125–126}}</ref> The tower was featured on the front of prominent magazines such as ''[[Scientific American]]'', as well as on the sides of [[corn flake]] boxes, coffee packets, and cars.<ref name=MoudryPP126>{{harvnb|Moudry|2005b|pp=126–127}}</ref>{{refn|Metropolitan Life valued the free publicity surrounding its skyscraper building at over $440,000 ($198 million in 2010 terms).<ref name=MoudryPP126/>|group=nb}} The tower was loosely modeled on the Venician [[St Mark's Campanile]], and featured extensive [[Renaissance architecture|Early Renaissance]]-style detailing, with the more modern additions of huge clock faces, electric floodlights for night-time illumination, and an observation deck at the top.<ref>{{harvnb|Moudry|2005b|p=125}}; {{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=361, 364–366}}</ref> Contemporary architects Everett Waid and Harvey Corbett described how the building had "the latest ideas in ventilation, air conditioning, sound deadening, artificial lighting, intercommunicating pneumatic tubes, telephones, call bells, unit operating clock systems [and] special elevator and escalator installations".<ref>{{harvnb|Waid|Corbett|2003|p=277}}</ref> The design won critical acclaim within the American architectural profession.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=366–367}}</ref>
The construction of the [[Woolworth Building]] was announced in 1910 by [[Frank Winfield Woolworth|Frank Woolworth]], who wanted to create the largest income-producing property in the U.S.<ref name=LandauConditPP381>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=381–382}}</ref> The project grew, and Woolworth finally opted for a 55-story, {{convert|792|ft|adj=on}} high skyscraper, the latest tallest building in the world, at a cost of $13.5 million ($5.1 billion in 2010 terms).<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=381–382}}; {{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|p=42}}</ref>{{refn|Prices in this article are given in US dollars throughout. Equivalent modern prices have been given in 2010 US dollars to two significant figures. The equivalent prices of modern goods and services – such as entry costs to skyscrapers – have been calculated using the Consumer Price Index (CPI). The CPI is not reliable for comparing the value of capital investment projects – such as the cost or value of early skyscrapers – over time, and these have been calculated using the relative share of GDP index.<ref>{{cite web| title = Seven Ways to Compute the Relative Value of a US Dollar Amount – 1774 to Present| publisher = MeasuringWorth| year = 2012| url = http://www.measuringworth.com/uscompare/ | accessdate = September 8, 2012}}</ref>|group=nb}} Architect [[Cass Gilbert]] designs included a very high proportion of usable – and thus rentable – floor space, with a great deal of light and a flexible floor plan that could be subdivided for different tenants.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=383–384}}</ref> Up-to-date fittings were installed to encourage a high-class of tenants, including the world's fastest elevators, safety features, and a swimming pool.<ref name="Landau 1996 386">{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|p=386}}</ref> Gilbert adopted the Beaux-Arts style, using accented terracotta and glass to emphasis vertical lines, elegantly echoing the structural frame underneath and incorporating 15th and 16th century [[Flamboyant Gothic]]-styled features. It was capped by a gilded tower that blended into the sky behind it to produce an illusion of even greater height.<ref>{{harvnb|Fenske|2005|pp=20. 29}}; {{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=384, 387}}; {{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|p=44}}</ref> The building was illuminated with floodlights at night, topped with red and white flashing lights.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|p=390}}</ref> It was famously dubbed the "Cathedral of Commerce", rather to Gilbert's displeasure as he had attempted to avoid copying ecclesiastical architecture.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=382, 387}}</ref>
Meanwhile, Chicago's skyscraper industry also boomed during the decade before [[World War I]]. The city's [[Chicago 'L'|elevated train network]] was operating by 1910, allowing more workers to come into the centre.<ref name=FineP66>{{harvnb|Fine|2005|p=66}}</ref> In 1910 alone {{convert|1500000|sqft|m2|sigfig=2}} of new offices were opened and by the end of the decade, Chicago had the second largest number of headquarters offices in the U.S.<ref name=FineP66/> Chicago architectural firms such as Daniel H. Burnham and then [[Graham, Anderson, Probst & White]] continued to design skyscrapers in the ''palazzo'' style made popular in the previous decade.<ref name="Willis 1995 58"/> Chicago had hosted the [[World's Columbian Exposition]] in 1893, a massive international event which had excited interest in the themes of classical architecture and well-designed city landscapes.<ref name="Willis 1995 59">{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=59}}</ref> Chicago also had extensive discussions in 1909 about the potential for designing large parts of the city, the [[Burnham Plan of Chicago]].<ref name="Willis 1995 59"/>
The resulting skyscrapers reflected these debates: the [[Santa Fe Building (Chicago)|Railway Exchange]], the [[Peoples Gas Building|Peoples Gas]] and the [[Continental Illinois|Illinois Continental and Commercial Bank Buildings]] were each substantial, quarter-block wide ''palazzo'' cubes of common height, their facades divided into a classical tripartite design, and sporting classical columns and other features.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=58–60}}</ref> Despite the apparent uniformity of design, individual buildings varied considerably in the detail of their designs in effort to express their particular identities, the Peoples Gas Building using texture and the Railway Exchange Building's white terracotta, for example.<ref>{{harvnb|Bruegmann|1997|p=141}}</ref>
===Improvements in construction=== [[File:Typical floor of the Flatiron Building.jpg|thumb|250px|Typical floor of the [[Flatiron Building]]]] The process of building skyscrapers became more sophisticated, starting with the acquisition of the real estate needed for the site.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=160–162}}</ref> Brokers working on commission would secretly acquire the individual lots of land required for a project, operating under a variety of names to avoid having the price increase once a planned build became known.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=160–161}}</ref> The properties at the front of the site would typically be bought first, so if news broke of the skyscraper then those owning property at the back of the plot would have little choice but to sell anyway.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=161}}</ref> The funding for skyscraper developments was normally lent by banks, insurance companies, or raised through [[Corporate bond|bonds]] sold through a specialised bond house, with the latter becoming increasingly popular after World War I.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=162}}</ref>
Efforts were made to improve the processes for erecting skyscrapers, largely through the work of general contractors such as Louis Horowitz and [[Frank Bunker Gilbreth, Sr.|Frank Gilbreth]], who in turn drew on recent work by efficiency specialist [[Frederick Winslow Taylor|Frederick Taylor]].<ref>{{harvnb|Fenske|2005|pp=32–33}}</ref> Time schedules were devised for all the work to be undertaken, with costs carefully monitored and reports produced each day.<ref name=FenskeP33>{{harvnb|Fenske|2005|p=33}}</ref> The results were demonstrated on the Woolworth Building construction project, where {{convert|1153|t|kg}} of steel were assembled in only six days, a record for the period.<ref name=FenskeP33/> Improved windbracing techniques were introduced.<ref name="Landau 1996 357"/> The use of pneumatic [[Caisson (engineering)|caissons]] in skyscraper foundations grew more advanced; in the construction of the 1908 [[Manhattan Municipal Building]] they were successfully sunk {{convert|144|ft}} below the surface, with specially conditioned workers operating in shifts with constant medical support.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=373–374}}</ref>
New technologies were also introduced within the buildings. Fast [[Otis Elevator Company|Otis]] elevators, powered by electricity rather than steam-driven hydraulics, began to be installed in skyscrapers, with Ellithorpe safety air cushions protecting the passengers in the case of failure.<ref name="Landau 1996 386"/> Lighting improved, with the recommended levels in 1916 being around twice the level of the 1890s.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=24–25}}</ref> Nonetheless, skyscrapers still relied primarily on natural sunlight, which required installing large windows and having tall ceilings to allow the sunlight to penetrate the back of the offices; an office deeper than {{convert|28|ft}} was not considered a practical design.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=25–26}}</ref>
===Life in the skyscrapers=== [[File:Met Life Acturial Office, 1910.jpg|thumb|left|Working conditions in the [[Metropolitan Life Insurance Company Tower]], 1910]]
One of the reasons for the increase in the numbers of skyscrapers during the period was the growth in demand for office workers. In part this demand was fuelled by many U.S. firms becoming larger and more complex, and white-collar sectors such as insurance and banking grew in scale.<ref>{{harvnb|Goldin|Katz|2008|p=172}}</ref> It was also driven by changing technology. The typewriter was joined in the office by the [[adding machine]], the telephone and filing cabinets, all adding to the demand for office space and requiring increasingly specialised workers.<ref>{{harvnb|Goldin|Katz|2008|pp=172–173}}</ref>
Tenants and rental income were essential to the financial success of any skyscraper, as even the largest skyscrapers and those founded by prominent companies rented out much of their office space.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=147–148}}</ref> Owners could charge significantly more for office space close to the main windows, making it most efficient to build skyscrapers with as much premium office space as possible, even if this cost slightly more to construct in the first instance.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=26–27}}</ref> As a result, a standard pattern for office units in both New York and Chicago emerged, with either a single rectangular office adjoining an exterior wall, or a "T" shaped design, with a reception room giving way to two windowed offices, separated by glass partitions.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=27–28}}</ref> Skyscrapers usually took on large numbers of relatively small companies as their tenants. A skyscraper such as the Woolworth Tower had around 600 different tenants in 1913, for example, while a typical tenant might rent four or five office units in a skyscraper.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=28–29, 148}}</ref>
===Criticism === [[File:Stieglitz-NewYorkOldNew.jpg|thumb|[[Alfred Stieglitz]]'s 1910 work ''Old and New New York'', showing the Vanderbilt Hotel under construction]]
Skyscrapers, particularly those in New York, attracted considerable comment, much of it negative. On his return to New York, writer [[Henry James]] condemned the buildings in ''The American Scene'' as simply "giants of the mere market", "mercenary monsters" doomed to be torn down in turn as other, even larger, buildings took their place.<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|p=8}}; {{harvnb|Bragdon|2003|p=155}}</ref> In Chicago the combination of the environmental pollution and skyscrapers meant that, as Charles Warner complained, "one can scarcely see across the streets on a damp day, and the huge buildings loom up in the black sky in ghostly dimness".<ref>{{harvnb|Cronon|1992|p=12}}</ref>
Wider artistic sentiments varied. Many, like, [[Alfred Stieglitz]] harboured mixed feelings over New York's skyscrapers, reflected in his famous 1903 portrait of the [[Flatiron building]], and his 1910 work ''Old and New New York'' that contrasts the growing steel frame of the emerging Vanderbilt Hotel with the old low-rise blocks of the street below.<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|pp=42–44}}</ref> Poets also wrote about the issues, the [[Modernist poetry|early Modernist]] [[Sadakichi Hartmann]] describing how "from the city's stir and madd'ning roar" the Flatiron's "monstrous shape soars in massive flight".<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|p=46}}</ref> Artists such as [[Alvin Langdon Coburn|Alvin Coburn]] and [[John Marin]] experimented with producing portraits of New York's skyscrapers, capturing the positive and negative aspects of the modern structures.<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|pp=46–55}}</ref> In 1908 artist Harry Pettit produced a romantic interpretation of a future New York, filled with giant skyscrapers supporting aerial bridges and receiving dirigibles from around the globe.<ref>{{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|pp=9–10}}</ref>
Amongst the architectural community, the Exposition in Chicago inspired many in America to champion planning cities that had a unified design, in which each building had unique features but elegantly complemented its neighbours, typically by being built to a common height: "horizontal visual unity".<ref>{{harvnb|Revell|2005|pp=38–39}}</ref> In the aftermath of the Exposition, many of these advocates joined with the Beaux-Arts movement to form the [[City Beautiful movement]], proposing low-rise cities with wide boulevards, built in a classical style.<ref>{{harvnb|Revell|2005|p=30}}</ref> These critics condemned New York's skyscrapers, [[Montgomery Schuyler]] describing how they had produced a "horribly jagged sierra" of a city skyline and complaining that no modern skyscraper had turned out to be an architectural success.<ref>{{harvnb|Schuyler|1961|p=443}} cited {{harvnb|Revell|2005|p=39}}; {{harvnb|Revell|2005|pp=39–40}}</ref> [[Charles Rollinson Lamb|Charles Lamb]] argued that the skyscraper impinged on the rights of the rest of the city by destroying the collective appearance of an urban area.<ref>{{harvnb|Lamb|1898|p=57}} cited {{harvnb|Revell|2005|pp=41–42}}</ref> Some architects, such as [[Charles Follen McKim|Charles McKim]] and [[Stanford White]] refused to work on such projects altogether.<ref name="Fenske 2005 22"/>
===Reform in New York===
Calls were made in New York for legislation to prevent the growth of skyscrapers, citing their effect on the city skylines, but these attempts faced legal obstacles. The [[United States Constitution]] did not give local government authority to prevent the buildings on the grounds of aesthetics alone, and any such law in New York was considered likely to face judicial challenge.<ref>{{harvnb|Revell|2005|pp=42–43}}</ref>
Others argued that legal reform of skyscraper construction was needed for public health and safety reasons, an area in which U.S. law was normally more supportive of state intervention.<ref name=RevellP43/> The risk of fire was one concern; while skyscrapers might be relatively fireproof, their height made conventional fire-fighting difficult. Architect Charles Bragdon considered a large scale, devastating high-rise fire to be inevitable if regulation was not forthcoming.<ref>{{harvnb|Bragdon|2003|pp=155–156}}</ref> The [[Great Baltimore Fire|Baltimore fire of 1904]] was widely cited as an example of this risk and, although Baltimore had few high rise buildings, city lawyers argued that the taller buildings had caused the flames to spread through the city during the blaze.<ref name=RevellP43/> Baltimore subsequently passed a law in 1904, banning buildings higher than {{convert|70|ft}}.<ref name=RevellP43/> Other campaigners argued that skyscrapers were compromising access to light and air, noting that when tall buildings rose straight up from the sidewalk, they cast long shadows across the street, preventing healthy sunlight from reaching smaller buildings below.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|pp=393–395}}</ref>
[[File:Equitable Building.jpg|thumb|left|The [[Equitable Building (Manhattan)|Equitable Building]] in 2011, showing the effect of pre-zoning skyscrapers when seen from the sidewalk]] Early attempts by [[Ernest Flagg]] to limit the height of New York's skyscrapers in 1896 failed; further unsuccessful attempts followed between 1906 and 1908, and legislation was turned down again in 1909, partially because of pressure from the real estate industry.<ref name=WillisP68>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=68}}</ref> After 1913, however, the property market in New York entered a recession, and vacancy levels in buildings began to rise.<ref name=WillisP68/> The campaign for change was helped by the construction of the [[Equitable Building (Manhattan)|Equitable Building]] in 1915 at the estimated cost of $29 million ($10.9 billion in 2010 terms), which rapidly became infamous as its vast height and bulk blocked views cast neighbours into permanent shade.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=69}}; {{harvnb|American Art Publishing|1918|p=11}}</ref> The real estate industry finally ceased its objections to new legislation, and the [[1916 Zoning Resolution]] was passed.<ref name=WillisP68/>
The details of the legislation were largely the work of architect George Ford. Ford had sympathies with the City Beautiful movement, disliked the unimaginative form of many New York skyscrapers, and had concerns over urban public health, but he also found tall buildings exciting and believed that horizontal visual unity produced boring architecture.<ref>{{harvnb|Revell|2005|pp=47–48}}</ref> As a consequence of Ford's influence, New York's laws were relatively complex and divided up the city into different zones; in each zone, a particular [[Zoning in the United States|zoning envelope]] applied, controlling the height to which buildings could be built.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=67}}; {{harvnb|Revell|2005|pp=48–49}}</ref> Typically a building could only rise up from the sidewalk vertically by around {{convert|100|ft}}, after which the building had to be [[setback (architecture)|set back]] at a set angle to allow sunlight to reach the street below.<ref name=WillisP67>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=67}}</ref> On a quarter of the site, however, the owner could build as high as they wished, without any further restrictions.<ref name=WillisP67/>
==Inter-war period, boom and depression: 1920–39==
===Post-war boom=== [[File:Kavanagh building.jpg|thumb|250px|The [[Kavanagh Building]], Buenos Aires, in 2009]] A real estate boom occurred in the U.S. after the end of the First World War, with a particular surge in the construction of new skyscrapers between 1925 and 1931.<ref name="Schleier 1986 69">{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|p=69}}</ref> In New York, a quarter of the financial district was rebuilt between 1928 and 1931, with {{convert|17000000|sqft|m2|sigfig=2}} of new office space added between 1925 and 1929 alone.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=165}}; {{harvnb|Abramson|2001|p=xi}}</ref> In Chicago, limited wartime construction created supply shortages, and rent levels rose in response by around 100 percent between 1919 and 1924.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=109}}</ref> This level of potential profits encouraged an explosion of new building projects in the city.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=109–110}}</ref> The boom inflated prices in the real estate market, leading to speculative financing and building projects, including the introduction of 100 percent mortgages for new builds. An early edition of the ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' magazine commented wryly that "all a man needs to own a skyscraper is the money and the land. And he may be able to get along without the money."<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=109–110, 165}}</ref>
Skyscrapers continued to grow in height throughout the 1920s.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=41, 85}}</ref> In part this was the result of improvements in technology: steel-frame structures had become increasingly efficient, while improvements in elevator design made taller buildings easier to ascend.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=41–42}}; {{harvnb|Abramson|2001|p=84}}</ref> Commercial factors were at work too, as growing commercial demand pushed up rents, enabling taller projects, while the higher offices attracted more sunlight, permitting the charging of premium rents.<ref name=WillisPP42>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=42–43}}</ref> The tallest buildings could also acquire publicity for their owners, in turn making it easier to find and keep the best tenants.<ref name=WillisPP42/> Furthermore, the higher the cost of the underlying real estate, the taller a building needed to be to generate a suitable return on the investment, and the minimum sensible commercial height for a skyscraper project grew to between 40 and 45 stories.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=85}}; {{harvnb|Clark|Kingston|1930}}, cited {{harvnb|Abramson|2001|p=55}}</ref> 70 story skyscrapers became relatively common, although an influential 1930 study demonstrated that the best rate of return on a skyscraper was to build it 63 stories high, returning an annual profit of 10.25 percent.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=86–88}}</ref>
[[File:Terminal Tower ceiling.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Main entrance to Cleveland's [[Terminal Tower]] in 2012]] Skyscrapers continued to spread both across the U.S. and internationally. New York and Chicago remained the center of skyscraper development, but most major cities in the U.S. had built skyscrapers by 1929, frequently as a result of competition between rival cities for status and investment.<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|p=69}}; {{harvnb|Ford|2005|p=53}}; {{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=9}}</ref> [[Cincinnati]] built the Cincinnati Towers in 1914, followed by the [[Carew Tower|Carew Tower Complex]] in 1930.<ref name="Ford 2005 36–37, 39">{{harvnb|Ford|2005|pp=36–37, 39}}</ref> In [[Detroit]], the [[Cadillac Place|General Motors Building]] opened in 1920 and the [[Fisher Building]] in 1928.<ref name="Douglas 1996 85">{{harvnb|Douglas|1996|p=85}}</ref> [[Cleveland]] acquired the [[Huntington Bank Building|Union Trust Building]] in 1923 and the [[Terminal Tower]] in 1929; the latter, built by the [[Van Sweringen brothers]], was, for a short period, the second tallest building in the world.<ref>{{harvnb|Douglas|1996|p=85}}; {{harvnb|Ford|2005|p=38}}</ref> [[Seattle]] had built [[Smith Tower]] in 1914, and the [[Los Angeles]] local government granted itself an exemption from city planning restrictions in order to build the [[Los Angeles City Hall]] in 1928.<ref name="Ford 2005 36–37, 39"/> Also in 1928, the [[Industrial Trust Tower]] was built in [[Providence, Rhode Island|Providence]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Industrial Trust Company, Providence|url=http://www.ricurrency.com/bank-name/industrial-trust-company-providence/|publisher=RI Currency|accessdate=11 April 2014}}</ref>
Skyscrapers were also built in other developed countries, although reaching nowhere near the level of construction seen in the U.S.<ref name=GoldbergerP51>{{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|p=51}}</ref> This was partially the result of a lack of funding but also because of local architectural preferences.<ref name=GoldbergerP51/> European cities including London and Paris had laws to ban tall buildings, but elsewhere skyscrapers began to appear, including [[Toronto]]'s [[Commerce Court|Imperial Bank of Commerce Building]], [[Antwerp]]'s [[Boerentoren]] and [[Buenos Aires]]' [[Kavanagh Building]].<ref>{{harvnb|Clark|1991|p=157}}; {{harvnb|Binder|2006|p=64}}; {{harvnb|Ford|2005|p=25}}; {{harvnb|Walter|1993|p=205}}</ref> Many other European skyscrapers were proposed in a frenzy of excited planning, although few materialised.<ref>{{harvnb|Solomonson|2001|pp=72–73}}</ref> Soviet Russia began the construction of the {{convert|1365|ft|adj=on}} [[Palace of the Soviets]] in the late 1930s, in the [[Stalinist architecture|Socialist Classicism]] style, which would have become the tallest building in the world, but war intervened and the skyscraper was never completed.<ref>{{harvnb|Binder|2006|p=10}}</ref> In the post-war years, this style resulted in the monumental [[Seven Sisters (Moscow)|Seven Sisters of Moscow]] building.<ref>{{harvnb|Paperny|2002}}</ref>
The technology used in constructing skyscrapers continued to develop. Time was increasingly a factor in the projects, and architects and their specialist teams developed faster ways to design and construct the buildings to minimise the interest payments during construction and hasten the arrival of rental income.<ref>{{harvnb|Abramson|2001|pp=44–45, 79}}</ref> By 1930, skyscrapers were being erected in just 12 months by teams of workers totalling 5,000 men, with four floors being assembled in a typical week.<ref>{{harvnb|Abramson|2001|p=74}}</ref> Building skyscraper towers involved some adaption of engineering techniques, as effectively two different buildings were being designed – the base and the tower – which needed to be efficiently linked using elevators and other service facilities.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=83–85}}</ref> Most new offices settled around a standard size, {{convert|9|ft}} wide by {{convert|20|to|30|ft|abbr=on}} deep, depending on the height of the ceiling, with multiple small windows considered better than a few larger ones.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=81}}; {{harvnb|Abramson|2001|p=69}}</ref> The output of electric lighting continued to improve, although this began to give off excessive heat within the offices.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=25}}</ref> Air conditioning was first installed in a few skyscrapers during the 1930s.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=26}}.</ref>
===Art Deco skyscrapers and New York's set-back style=== [[File:40 Wall Street IMG 9048.JPG|thumb|The [[40 Wall Street|Bank of Manhattan Trust Building]] in 2010, showing the setback style]] During the 1920s and 1930s many skyscrapers were designed in an [[Art Deco]] style.<ref>{{harvnb|Watkin|2005|p=580}}</ref>{{refn|The definition of architectural styles is usually imprecise. "Art Deco" was often termed "moderne" during the 1920s, and historians such as Daniel Abramson draw further contrast between styles during the period that stressed traditional, often [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic]] features; classic Art Deco styles; and more minimalist versions towards the end of the period.<ref>{{harvnb|Abramson|2001|pp=96–119}}</ref>|group=nb}} This architectural approach typically combined what Carol Willis terms an "aesthetic of simple, sculptural mass" with the use of rich colour and ornamentation on the surfaces of the buildings.<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|p=114}}; {{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=77–79}}</ref> The aim was to call attention to the increasingly complex three-dimensional shape of the skyscraper, in contrast to earlier styles which could be critiqued, as historian Larry Ford suggests, as being merely "short buildings made taller with additional stories".<ref>{{harvnb|Ford|2005|p=37}}; {{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|p=19}}</ref> Windows were de-emphasised in favour of creating a strong sense of shape and mass, the surrounding walls treated as textured fabric, dressing the building underneath.<ref>{{harvnb|Shepherd|2003|p=259}}; {{harvnb|Abramson|2001|p=49}}</ref> Skyscrapers of this period typically lost their ornamental horizontal divisions, being broken up by physical changes in their shape as one looked up the building, the whole forming a striking silhouette.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=102}}; {{harvnb|Shepherd|2003|p=259}}</ref>
In New York, the 1916 act to allow light and air to reach the streets encouraged a stepped or [[ziggurat]] approach to skyscraper design; this "set-back" style often made unrestricted use of the 25 percent of the site allowed by law to complete with a very tall tower.<ref name="WillisP67"/> This encouraged a diversity of buildings, while maintaining an element of harmony and consistency of style.<ref>{{harvnb|Revell|2005|p=51}}</ref> The [[Paramount Building]] and [[120 Wall Street]], for example, were constructed in the set-back style without towers, partially because the limited size of the sites would have made the towers relatively narrow and – when packed with the necessary elevators and service facilities – economically unviable.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=72–73, 76}}</ref> Many other skyscrapers built on larger or more expensive plots opted for the tallest towers possible, including the $24 million ($3.8 billion in 2010 terms) [[Bank of Manhattan Trust Building]] and the [[City Bank-Farmers Trust Company Building]].<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=72–73}}; {{harvnb|Abramson|2001|p=29}}</ref> New York continued its lead in tall skyscrapers throughout the period; in 1920 it had ten times the number of tall buildings than its nearest rival Chicago.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=9–10}}</ref>
Some New York skyscrapers complemented traditional, cubicle offices linked by corridors, with larger, more open-plan spaces called "general offices".<ref name=AbramsonP2001>{{harvnb|Abramson|2001|p=122}}</ref> These maximised the number of workers that could be fitted into a given space and provided for greater flexibility.<ref name=AbramsonP2001/> Expensive corporate suites were also created during the 1930s, especially on Wall Street, typically on the highest levels of the buildings.<ref>{{harvnb|Abramson|2001|p=123}}</ref> These were used by the corporate executives and were usually lavishly outfitted in a range of traditional and exotic styles.<ref>{{harvnb|Abramson|2001|pp=123–125}}</ref> The lobbies of these skyscrapers remained grand affairs, although some banks now eschewed renting out space to shops and restaurants in favour of a more exclusive atmosphere.<ref>{{harvnb|Abramson|2001|pp=140–145}}</ref> The largest skyscrapers held up to 16,000 workers, although between 5,000 and 10,000 was more common, and the buildings held a wide range of services to support them, including beauty salons, private luncheon clubs, chiropodists and gymnasiums.<ref>{{harvnb|Abramson|2001|pp=155–156}}</ref> A skyscraper such as the [[70 Pine Street|Cities Service Building]] directly employed over 200 staff to manage and protect the property.<ref>{{harvnb|Abramson|2001|pp=157–158}}</ref> The technology within the offices also grew still more sophisticated, with [[Dictation machine|dictating]], automatic typing and [[tabulating machine]]s being used by teams of ever more specialised office workers.<ref>{{harvnb|Goldin|Katz|2008|pp=173–14}}</ref>{{refn|In 1895, there were 15 well-defined roles in U.S. offices, with generalised labels such as clerks, office boys and bookkeepers; by 1922 increased specialisation meant that this had risen to 22, and by 1940 over a hundred distinct roles existed, including accountants, auditors, payroll clerks, stenographers, receptionists, machine operators and file clerks.<ref>{{harvnb|Goldin|Katz|2008|p=174}}; {{harvnb|Abramson|2001|pp=160–161}}</ref>|group=nb}}
===Chicago's towers=== [[File:Chicago 29 Oct116.jpg|thumb|left|The [[Tribune Tower]] was one of the most famous buildings of the 1920s.]] Chicago altered its laws in the 1920s to allow towers to be built as part of its skyscrapers. In 1920, the maximum building height in Chicago was increased to {{convert|260|ft}}, and unoccupied structures on a building, such as ornamental towers, were allowed to extend up to {{convert|400|ft}} high.<ref name=WillisP111>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=111}}</ref> Additional changes came in 1923, with taller occupied towers being permitted for the first time, but subject to controls on overall volumes.<ref name="Willis 1995 23"/> The main building of a skyscraper could be up to {{convert|264|ft}} tall, and a tower could be built on up to 25 percent of the lot, but the tower could not have a volume of more than a sixth of the main block.<ref name=WillisP111/> In practice, this meant that a tower could not be built more than around 20 stories tall in a typical Chicago skyscraper development.<ref name=WillisP111/>
Initially, Chicago still preferred ''palazzo''-styled buildings with large light courts in the centre, because they remained the most profitable designs.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=49, 111}}</ref> The [[Wrigley Building]], built under the 1920 law, demonstrated the effect of two ornamental towers on top of a skyscraper.<ref name=WillisP111/> Under the revised law, the [[Metropolitan Tower (Chicago)|Straus Building]] and the [[Pittsfield Building]] took the ''palazzo'' design and added somewhat stunted towers on top in the early 1920s, producing profitable buildings.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=112–113, 117}}</ref>
One of the period's most famous buildings, the [[Tribune Tower]], emerged from a [[architectural design competition|competition]] held by the [[Tribune Company]] in 1922 to celebrate its 75th anniversary.<ref name="Solomonson 2005 147">{{harvnb|Solomonson|2005|p=147}}</ref> The newspaper was one of the largest in the world and used the competition, in which members of the public were invited to influence the design of the skyscraper, to build a loyal following amongst its readership and generate free publicity.<ref>{{harvnb|Solomonson|2005|pp=148–150}}</ref> The final design was determined by a competition panel largely made up of the company's appointees, who chose [[John Mead Howells|John Howells]] and [[Raymond Hood]]'s tower design.<ref>{{harvnb|Solomonson|2005|p=156}}</ref> The resulting tower was a conservative, Gothic design and controversy about the decision broke out almost immediately: Louis Sullivan and many others criticized Howells and Hood's design as being derivative of the Woolworth Tower.<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|p=112}}; {{harvnb|Solomonson|2005|p=158}}; {{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|p=51}}</ref> Regardless of its critics, the Tribune received as many as 20,000 visitors to its observation gallery when it opened in 1925.<ref name="Solomonson 2005 147"/> The unbuilt [[Eliel Saarinen's Tribune Tower design|second-place entry in the competition]], a more simplified stepped-back design by [[Eliel Saarinen]], also proved highly influential.<ref name="Solomonson 2005 147"/>
The popularity of the older style then began to wane in favor of a greater emphasis on towers.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=117}}</ref> One common way of building these within Chicago's laws was to build a square main block with a central service core, and then simply place a tower on the top; the more massive the main block, the taller the tower could be.<ref name=WillisPP118>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=118–119}}</ref> The [[Trustees System Service Building]] and the Foreman State National Bank Building form good examples of this approach.<ref name=WillisPP118/> Alternatively, the front of the main block could be recessed, as at the [[Civic Opera House (Chicago)|Chicago Civic Opera Building]] or the [[LaSalle-Wacker Building]], sacrificing volume but producing the visual effect of two high wings flanking a very tall tower.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=120–121}}</ref> The distinctive New York "setback" style was not adopted in Chicago, the only example of this style being the [[Palmolive Building]] on North Michigan Avenue.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=125}}</ref>
===Great Depression=== [[File:Empire State Building by David Shankbone.jpg|thumb|The [[Empire State Building]] in 2007]] The boom in skyscraper construction began to falter following the [[Wall Street Crash of 1929]], with fast economic growth giving way to the slump years of the [[Great Depression]]: construction of all sorts slowed considerably.<ref name="Shepherd 2003 226">{{harvnb|Shepherd|2003|p=226}}</ref> The real estate market that lay behind new skyscraper builds collapsed, and the value of many properties dropped dramatically: the [[LeVeque Tower|American Insurance Union]] tower cost $8 million ($1.2 billion in 2010 terms) to build in 1927, but was valued at only $3.5 million ($900 million) by 1933; the Bank of Manhattan Trust Building defaulted on its debts in 1935 and was put on sale for just $1.2 million ($240 m).<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=164}}; {{harvnb|Ford|2005|p=41}}; {{harvnb|Abramson|2001|p=29}}</ref>{{refn|Put on sale for $1.2 million, the Bank of Manhattan Trust Building was valued at less than the original cost of its elevators. Skyscraper values during the Depression years should be seen against a context of [[deflation]] and a shrinking economy.<ref>{{harvnb|Abramson|2001|p=29}}</ref>|group=nb}} The major bond house of S.W. Straus, behind many successful developments, defaulted on the $214 million ($47 billion) in bonds held by 60,000 investors; the Van Swerigan developer brothers went bankrupt.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=164}}; {{harvnb|Ford|2005|p=41}}</ref> Vacancy rates began to increase as the recession bit, increasing from only one percent in central New York in early 1920 to 17 percent in 1931 and 25 percent by 1934.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=165}}</ref>
In the face of the recession, some skyscrapers projects were canceled or scaled back. Plans by the Metropolitan Life company to build a 100-story skyscraper alongside their existing tower had been put forward in 1929, but were shelved in the face of the recession and public criticism of such expenditure in the economic climate.<ref>{{harvnb|Moudry|2005b|pp=137–138}}</ref> Instead the first phase of the project, known as the [[Metropolitan Life North Building|North Building]] ended up only 32 stories high in 1932 and the building, even at this height, was only fully completed in 1950.<ref>{{harvnb|Moudry|2005b|p=138}}</ref> In many other cases, projects which had already been commissioned continued through to completion. This resulted in {{convert|26000000|sqft|m2|sigfig=2}} of new office space being added to New York between 1931–34 even after the start of the recession, adding to the problem of underoccupancy.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=88}}</ref> Some of these buildings, however, became iconic structures, pushing the limits of skyscraper height sharply upwards.<ref>{{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|p=77}}</ref>
The [[Chrysler Building]] was completed in 1930, just after the Depression began to affect the industry.<ref>{{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|p=79}}</ref> Architect [[William Van Alen]] competed with the designers of the Bank of Manhattan Trust Building to produce the tallest building in the world and famously erected the Chrysler spire in a last-minute, secret move in order to acquire the title for his own 69-story, {{convert|1046|ft|adj=on}} tall building.<ref>{{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|pp=82–83}}; {{harvnb|Douglas|1996|p=96}}</ref> The exterior was built of white and grey brick, but metal was used extensively to ornament it further, including gargoyles, [[nickel]]-[[Chrome plating|chrome]] eagles' heads, and a winged helmet of [[Mercury (mythology)|Mercury]].<ref>{{harvnb|Douglas|1996|p=96}}; {{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|p=80}}</ref> The entrance used black granite to contrast with the nickel-chrome windows, and the foyer gave way to red marble and a mural ceiling.<ref>{{harvnb|Douglas|1996|p=97}}</ref> The design of each part of the building was individualist and distinct, with even each elevator different in design.<ref name="Douglas 1996 85"/> A [[Chrysler]] showroom was placed on the first floor of the building and an observation deck and the exclusive "Cloud Club" on the upper levels.<ref>{{harvnb|Douglas|1996|pp=97–97}}</ref>
[[File:Rockefeller Center, December 1933.jpg|thumb|left|The [[Rockefeller Center]] at night, 1933]] The [[Empire State Building]] originated from a 1928 project to redevelop the [[Waldorf-Astoria Hotel]] into a 50-story mixed-use development; the purchase of the site for $14 million ($2.1 billion) set a record in New York for the year.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=90}}</ref> [[John J. Raskob|John Raskob]] and [[Pierre S. du Pont|Pierre du Pont]] entered into the project as financial backers, and concluded that the project would be more profitable if the site was used to build an extremely tall 80-story skyscraper instead.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=90–95}}</ref> Although revised financial estimates suggested that the height should be cut back, the caché of having the world's tallest building was considerable, and instead an additional five stories were added to ensure the building, at {{convert|1050|ft}}, would be slightly taller than the Chrysler building.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=98–99}}</ref> An observation deck was built to attract tourists, which proved to be a valuable source of revenue.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=100}}</ref> The [[limestone]], [[granite]], and [[aluminium]] skyscraper was specially designed to be easily erected, with standardized paneling and structural fittings, and was completed in only 18 months, opening in 1931.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=100–101}}; {{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|p=85}}</ref> Due to the recession, however, it was only 25 percent occupied throughout the 1930s and ran at a loss; critics dubbed it the "Empty State Building".<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=90}}; {{harvnb|Schleier|1986|p=120}}</ref>
The [[Rockefeller Center]] had originally been intended by [[John D. Rockefeller, Jr.]] to be a new location for the [[Metropolitan Opera House (39th St)|Metropolitan Opera House]], but the Stock Market Crash brought an end to the scheme.<ref>{{harvnb|Krinsky|2005|pp=203–204}}</ref> Rockefeller decided to develop a large office center instead, taking advantage of the low construction costs during the recession.<ref>{{harvnb|Krinsky|2005|pp=202–204, 208}}; {{harvnb|Ford|2005|p=43}}</ref> At the center of the development was the RCA Building, heavily influenced by architect Raymond Hood.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=103}}</ref> The long, slab-like RCA had two distinct axes – from one side, it appeared to be a narrow tower, from the other it rose like a sheer wall.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=105}}</ref> Not only was the structure highly distinctive, but it was also economically very effective. The design maximized the available light to the offices and eliminated any darker internal rooms, as the core of the building was entirely taken up with elevators and other engineering services.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=106}}</ref> It took until 1940 before all of the building had been filled by tenants.<ref>{{harvnb|Krinsky|2005|p=208}}</ref>
In Chicago, the final pre-war skyscraper was built in 1934.<ref name="Willis 1995 128–129">{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=128–129}}</ref> The [[Field Building (Chicago)|Field Building]] was commissioned during the final boom years of the inter-war economy, and the Home Insurance Building – the first skyscraper, built in 1884 – was demolished to make way for the "wing and tower"-style development.<ref name="Willis 1995 128–129"/>
===Skyscraper mania and social commentary=== [[File:Construction old and new from Washington Street 37 in Manhattan in1936 trimmed.jpg|thumb|[[Berenice Abbott]]'s depiction of changing Manhattan, 1936; Cunard Building (r)]] Public interest in skyscrapers increased during the 1920s, particularly after the Tribune competition.<ref name=SchleierP70>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|p=70}}</ref> The competition drawings were circulated on display, with 25,000 people coming to see them in Chicago in just one month.<ref name=SchleierP71>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|p=71}}</ref> In the aftermath, images of skyscrapers flourished across American culture, commencing what historian Merrill Schleier dubbed a "skyscraper mania".<ref name="Schleier 1986 69"/> The "Titan City" exhibition in 1925 celebrated existing skyscraper and featured futuristic murals by [[Harvey Wiley Corbett|Harvey Corbett]] and [[Hugh Ferriss]], depicting the skyscraper at the heart of the "City of the Future".<ref name=SchleierP70/> [[Charles Sheeler]] and [[Paul Strand]]'s 1921 short film ''[[Manhatta]]'' explored the form, ending with a sunset shot from the top of a skyscraper.<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|p=79}}</ref> Authors such as [[Janet Flanner]], [[John Dos Passos]] and [[Mary Borden]] wrote novels with skyscrapers as important motifs or settings.<ref name=SchleierP71/> [[John Alden Carpenter|John Carpenter]] produced a [[ballet]] on the theme.<ref name=SchleierP71/> [[Paul T. Frankl|Paul Frankl]] designed a range of popular "skyscraper furniture".<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|p=11}}</ref>
Much of this commentary was positive, reflecting an optimism about technology and the direction of urban life in general.<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|pp=72–73}}</ref> Skyscrapers were seen as an expression of rational engineering, the perfect buildings for mankind to live in, as celebrated in artist [[Louis Lozowick]]'s [[lithograph]]s.<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|pp=76–77}}; {{harvnb|Abramson|2001|p=177}}</ref> Some other proponents of skyscrapers likened them to medieval cathedrals, symbols of the modern age.<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|p=77}}</ref> Poems depicted skyscrapers as objects of sublime, rational beauty, Ferris describing them as "buildings like crystals, walls of translucent glass, sheer glass blocks sheathing a steel grill".<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|p=88}}</ref> At Chicago's [[Century of Progress]] exposition in 1933, skyscrapers and technology were portrayed as a solution for America's current and future problems.<ref name="Shepherd 2003 226"/> The French-Swiss architect [[Le Corbusier]] acclaimed New York in 1935 as being "overwhelming, amazing, exciting, violently alive", but went on to complain that there were still too few skyscrapers, and those that had been built were not yet tall enough.<ref>{{harvnb|Le Corbusier|1947|p=45}} cited {{harvnb|Page|2005|p=181}}</ref> [[Lewis Hine]], employed to record the building of the Empire State Building, portrayed the skyscraper construction teams as courageous heroes, creating a genre of photography that continued up until 1941.<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|p=121}}</ref>
[[File:Old timer structural worker2.jpg|thumb|left|A worker constructing the [[Empire State Building]] in 1930, overlooking the [[Chrysler Building]] in the background (r), by [[Lewis Hine]]]] Their critics expressed concerns about the effect of modern technology and urban living on the human condition, arguing that skyscrapers generated pollution and noise, and imposed a regimented and dehumanising lifestyle on the people that worked in them.<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|pp=72, 94–95}}</ref> Social commentator [[Lewis Mumford]] reflected the concerns of many in his critiques entitled ''Is the Skyscraper Tolerable?'' and ''The Intolerable City''.<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|p=93}}</ref> Political theorist [[Stefan Hirsch]] condemned the buildings as "bandages covering the sky, stifling our breath".<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|1986|p=103}}</ref> Inventor [[Thomas Edison]] expressed fears that an uncontrolled expansion of skyscrapers would result in overcrowding and disaster.<ref>{{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|p=88}}</ref> Artist [[Howard Cook]]'s engravings critiqued the oppressive character of the new skyscrapers as they loomed over the traditional city.<ref>{{harvnb|Abramson|2001|p=172}}</ref> [[Berenice Abbott]]'s photographic studies of New York in the 1930s explored the complex theme of urban change and the effect of skyscrapers on the older ways of life in the city, echoing Steigler's work in the first decade of the century.<ref>{{harvnb|Page|2005|pp=165–167}}</ref>
Hollywood used skyscrapers extensively in popular films. ''The Skyscrapers of New York'' in 1906 became the first of many, and in the 1920s [[Harold Lloyd]] produced his five "skyscraper films", most prominently ''[[Safety Last!]]'', in which the hero dangles from a clock on the side of a Los Angeles building.<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|2009|pp=2–4}}</ref> In these early [[silent film|silent movies]], skyscrapers were closely associated with masculine identity; Lloyd's climbing of skyscrapers closely associated with his characters' transformation from young men into mature adults, and the winning of the heroine.<ref>{{harvnb|Schleier|2009|pp=3–4, 13}}</ref> The 1933 film [[King Kong (1933 film)|''King Kong'']] included another iconic use of the early skyscraper in its final scenes, as the giant ape scaled the Empire State Building shortly before his death; the scene can be interpreted as contrasting natural instinct with the insensitive rationality of the modern building and wider New York.<ref>{{harvnb|Ramirez|2004|p=175}}</ref>
==Legacy== [[File:90 West Street Building.jpg|thumb|The [[West Street Building]] in 1988, overshadowed by the modernist [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]]]] Skyscraper development paused during the years of the [[Second World War]]. Once development began again in the 1950s and 1960s, the skyscraper entered a different phase of development, usually called the [[International style (architecture)|international]] or [[Modern architecture|modern]] period. Some experimental designs in this style had been built in the U.S. using European architectural concepts in the early 1930s, most notably the [[Loews Philadelphia Hotel|Philadelphia Savings Fund Society]] and [[330 West 42nd Street|McGraw-Hill Building]]s.<ref>{{harvnb|Watkin|2005|p=581}}</ref> Post-war, their modernist themes were used in a new generation of skyscrapers. These stood alone on individual plots in the fashion of the Rockefeller Centre's RCA building, rather than as part of a row of buildings, forming huge slabs and towers featuring huge glass façades, breaking with earlier skyscraper traditions.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=134}}; {{harvnb|Goldberger|1985|p=101}}</ref> Inside, new technologies such as [[Fluorescent lamp|fluorescent lighting]] and widespread air-conditioning meant that many older architectural features such as light courts and operable windows were unnecessary.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|pp=132–134}}</ref>
The trend had substantial implications for many early skyscrapers. Some were redesigned to fit new tastes. Much of the ornate detail was removed from the Metropolitan Life Tower in the 1960s, for example, to fit contemporary, plainer fashions.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|p=361}}</ref> Many older skyscrapers could not be adapted, however, as they lacked the physical depth to build larger modern offices or the space for new service facilities.<ref>{{harvnb|Willis|1995|p=136}}</ref> Some were demolished to make way for new, larger structures. Amongst these was the Singer Tower, demolished in 1968 and replaced by the international style United States Steel Building.<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Condit|1996|p=366}}</ref> In the 21st century, buildings such as [[90 West Street]] have been renovated as upmarket housing, partially because of their extensive windows and access to sunlight.<ref name=NYT2004>{{cite web| title = 9/11's Miracle Survivor Sheds Bandages: a 1907 Landmark Will be Restored for Residential Use| publisher = New York Times| author = Glenn Collins| year = 2004| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2004/03/05/nyregion/9-11-s-miracle-survivor-sheds-bandages-1907-landmark-will-be-restored-for.html?pagewanted=3&src=pm. | accessdate = September 8, 2012}}</ref>
Critical discussion of early skyscrapers began from the 1880s onwards in the architectural community and continued across a growing cultural and academic community in the inter-war period.
